title: Can I wait a year to apply to college after I graduate from high school? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can wait, but why would you? You should apply during your senior year and then ask to defer your enrollment for a year. Depending on where you're applying, it could be difficult to justify why you waited. If you don't get in where you want to go, apply again. If you're already planning to take a gap year, why not just apply twice if necessary? Also, your school will almost certainly have resources in place to help all the seniors get what they need to get done for their applications. If you wait a year, you will be on your own. It also could be more difficult to get your transcripts sent out. Also, you won't be in the same mindset after a year as you will be in senior year. You will be eager to finish high school and will likely lose momentum after a year… This isn't a guarantee, of course, but following the herd on this one might be beneficial. Deferring enrollment will definitely be easier, though. I recently was accepted in the Brown University Class of 2023 and decided to defer my enrollment so I could go study Mandarin under NSLI-Y for a year (hence my being in the class of 2024). Everyone at Brown was super helpful in this process, and now I can make the most of my time away from school without worrying about where I will be going to school. Best of luck in your endeavors. By all means, do whatever is best for you. I would just recommend that you apply and then defer rather than wait a year then apply.

As others have said, a gap year is totally normal. You can apply and commit to a college before your gap year (so applying during senior year of high school), or you can actually do your applications during your gap year. If you don’t like how it went the first time around, you might even be doing your second round of apps during the gap year. However, you should be careful that you’re still doing something with your time during the year off. There are a lot of programs designed for this (gap years are really popular outside the US), or you could be working (at a normal Joe job, or even as a freelancer—pushing your limits while you can). But, colleges will likely care that you’re using your time productively. If you’re already enrolled somewhere for the next year, proving this may be a provision for them to allow you to take the gap year. If you’re just now applying, they aren’t going to want to accept someone who’s just “taking time off” without some explanation.

Sure, it is called a gap year. You can apply to college, get accepted, and take a year to start. It is a good way to make some money and also figure out exactly what you want to study and career path you want to pursue. You have to make sure the college has a provision for late admission. If you take a year to start the whole application process you might not get the school you want and you might not actually follow through and go to college. The longer you take to start the easier it is not to go.

Yes, you can. It's normal to take a year gap between your transition from high school to college. However, it is not a good a idea to delay that gap into several years. The sooner you’ll start, the better you’ll catch up with everyone your age, and be able to get a stable career after you graduated from a 4-years university.
